close_symbols: semantics of req_cls / MHD connection callback lifecycle (initialization and reuse of *req_cls)
explanation:
Explain why each symbol is needed to decide whether any controlling expression in ahc_cb is invariant:

- enum MHD_Result (MHD_YES, MHD_NO): Many conditionals compare function returns against MHD_YES/MHD_NO. The concrete enum values and their semantics are needed to know whether those comparisons can ever evaluate differently (i.e. whether a comparison is tautological or impossible).

- is_websocket_request: The first substantive conditional uses its return (MHD_NO == is_websocket_request(...)). You must know whether is_websocket_request can vary with its inputs (or if it is effectively constant) to determine if the controlling expression is invariant.

- MHD_lookup_connection_value and MHD_lookup_connection_value_n: These produce upg_header, con_header, ws_version_header and ws_key_header (and ret). The subsequent conditionals depend on their return values/pointer results and on key_size; you need their behavior (return codes and when they produce NULL/set key_size) to see if those conditionals can change at runtime.

- ws_get_accept_value: Its return (compared to MHD_NO) gates progression; you must know whether it can return different values (or is constant) to judge invariance of the controlling expression using its result.

- MHD_add_response_header: Several conditionals compare its return to MHD_YES; its possible return values and when it fails are necessary to determine if those checks are ever true/false (and thus whether they are invariant).

- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET and MHD_HTTP_VERSION_1_1: These constants are used in strcmp comparisons against the request method/version. Their exact string values and the possible method/version inputs are needed to determine if those strcmp-based conditionals are always the same.

- WS_SEC_WEBSOCKET_VERSION and MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SEC_WEBSOCKET_VERSION: Used to fetch and compare the Sec-WebSocket-Version header; need the constant version string to evaluate whether that comparison can ever be true/false.

- MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SEC_WEBSOCKET_KEY and WS_KEY_LEN: The lookup_n call sets ws_key_header and key_size and compares key_size to WS_KEY_LEN. Knowing the header name and expected length is required to decide whether that key_size comparison can be invariant.

- semantics of req_cls / MHD connection callback lifecycle (initialization and reuse of *req_cls): The very first conditional tests *req_cls == NULL and then mutates it to signal re-entrancy. To decide whether that controlling expression is invariant you must know how the caller/MHD invokes the callback and what initial/ongoing values of *req_cls are (i.e. whether it can ever be non-NULL at entry).

(Other called functions such as MHD_create_response_for_upgrade, MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response, free, strcmp, strlen are standard or used only after these conditionals; they are not required to decide whether the controlling expressions themselves are invariant.)
